items.content_html: 🛬 Landed and back home! That’s a wrap for 2023 air travel. 24 flights for over 16,000 miles, 9 airports, 2 countries, all on one airline. I’m not sure if that’s a record for me for distance (probably not) but I think it is for segments. Thanks go to @jmjordan for her recent post introducing me to this fun and useful app! I’m happy that I was able to go in and add past flights to my archive!
items.content_text: 🛬 Landed and back home! That’s a wrap for 2023 air travel. 24 flights for over 16,000 miles, 9 airports, 2 countries, all on one airline. I’m not sure if that’s a record for me for distance (probably not) but I think it is for segments. Thanks go to [@jmjordan](https://micro.blog/jmjordan) for her recent post introducing me to this fun and useful app! I’m happy that I was able to go in and add past flights to my archive!

items.content_html:
The latest silliness.

Inspired by @robb’s Intercept site (and being too lazy to build something that sophisticated) I picked up another OMG.lol address to launch my latest vanity project. I’m trying to build something similar, but with a tag-based, rather than hierarchical, approach.

I call it V.I.N.CENT because the name seems apropos and I really love that movie—and because “Intercept” was taken.

https://vincent.mihobu.lol/

items.content_html:
I’ve long wondered whether a schism is coming in the Catholic Church.

There’s been a long-simmering progressive movement (esp. in the US) putting pressure on Rome from the left. And increasingly, pressure from the extremely conservative faction, exemplified by Strickland, esp. in light of Pope Francis’ “love all, include all” hippie leanings. I wonder if he’ll have the strength and longevity to hold it all together.

https://www.wsj.com/us-news/pope-francis-fires-conservative-u-s-bishop-a32d7caa

On the ballot in Ohio is a citizen-initiated law that would legalize marijuana. If it passes, Ohioans will be allowed (beginning on 7 December) to grow up to six cannabis plants at home (or 12 if two or more adults live in the house).

It might be time to take up gardening.

items.content_html:
My idea to end the debate over Daylight Saving Time versus Standard Time forever

is to create Universal Variable Time, defined around four fixed times of day, EVERY DAY, as follows:

🌅 06:00 - Sunrise
🏞️ 12:00 - “Midday,” the time exactly between sunrise and sunset
🌇 18:00 - Sunset
🌃 00:00 - “Midnight,” the time exactly between sunset and sunrise

Let the scheduling begin.

#DST #DitchDST #EndDaylightSaving #DaylightSavingTime #StandardTimeForever #StandardTime

items.content_html:
Tonight the sun will set at 17:25 and The Reign of Darkness begins.

I hate winter time. For me, the issue isn’t so much the time CHANGE as it is the getting dark just as I’m finishing my work day, which makes it feel like I’m living in perpetual night. Very depressing. I’d much rather stay on DST year-round, but that’s not an option under current federal law. 🤔

Sears is still in business?

Since switching from Google Workspace to Fastmail, some messages that were going to spam now come to my inbox and vice-versa. And that’s okay, it’s part of the process. But today I got email from Sears. I didn’t even know they were still in business! All the Sears stores around here closed a long time ago.

#sears

items.content_html:
Nvidia is making it work

For all the hype around corporations being “innovative” it’s telling that so many CEOs are unwilling to actually innovate the workplace. Instead they continue to press workers to return to the office, which hasn’t actually changed much since the first “open office” spaces were introduced 100 years ago, and where many spend most of the day “collaborating” via videoconference. Wake up, it’s 2023.

Nvidia, a $1 trillion AI powerhouse, is fine with remote work—and is ignoring the return-to-office trend

In car-obsessed Columbus, walking is a very risky endeavor. Sidewalks (when they exist at all) are often placed immediately alongside fast-moving traffic with no buffer. Crosswalks function inconsistently throughout the city, in some cases having different behaviors from one block to the next. Worst of all is that throughout the metro area (not just in the city limits) driving is universal and walking is far outside the norm, making pedestrians invisible to drivers.

https://www.axios.com/newsletters/axios-columbus-34bc5e40-8bf4-4e6f-850c-016fcc7574fe.html
